content: How can I help you today?

I've been struggling to sleep, and it's starting to affect everything else in my life. My mind races at night, and I can't stop thinking about work, my family, and how stressed I feel. I'm not even sure where to start.

That sounds really tough to deal with, especially when it's affecting so many aspects of your life. Struggling to sleep and feeling overwhelmed by thoughts can make it hard to feel at ease or function well during the day. What do you think is most important to focus on right now?

I think it’s the work stress that’s keeping me up the most. I constantly worry about losing my job and how I’ll take care of my family if that happens. But I don’t know how to stop those thoughts—it feels like they just take over as soon as I try to sleep.

It makes sense that the stress about work and providing for your family feels overwhelming, especially at night when everything is quiet, and those thoughts seem louder. You care deeply about your responsibilities, and that shows your dedication, but it's taking a toll on your ability to rest. Have you found anything that helps, even a little, to calm your thoughts, or is this something you've been dealing with on your own?

Sometimes I try distracting myself with my phone, but honestly, it just makes things worse. I end up scrolling for hours, and it adds more thoughts to the mix. Other than that, I haven’t really figured out anything that works—everything just keeps building up.

It sounds like you're trying to distract yourself from those racing thoughts because they feel too overwhelming, but using your phone ends up making it harder to settle down. That’s frustrating, especially since you're really trying to find some relief. It seems like you're feeling caught between the stresses of work, your family responsibilities, and not being able to switch off at night. What do you think life could look like if you were able to manage this stress and get the sleep you need?

I guess if I could actually sleep, I’d feel more focused and capable at work, and maybe that would help me stress less about losing my job. I’d also have more energy to spend quality time with my kids instead of just feeling exhausted all the time. Honestly, I just want to feel like I’m doing a good job for my family, but it feels so hard to get there right now.

It sounds like being there for your family and feeling confident at work are really important to you—it’s clear how much you care about both. Right now, though, the exhaustion and stress have been holding things back, even though it's something you'd really like to improve. It's already a big step to recognize how sleep could be part of moving toward those goals. What do you think would make it easier to take that next step?

Responding to the counselor: "I'm not even sure what the next step would look like. I know I need to stop using my phone at night, but I don’t know what else to do with all these thoughts. I feel kind of stuck."

Feeling stuck can be so discouraging, especially when you’re already aware of one thing that might help but aren’t sure what else to do. You’ve identified that pausing the nighttime scrolling is something to consider, and you've been really open about how those racing thoughts are a challenge for you. That shows a lot of self-awareness. What kind of approach, even small, might feel manageable to start easing into more restful nights? Or is there something else you’d like to explore first?

I guess I could try something small, like writing down my thoughts before bed to get them out of my head, but honestly, I’m not sure if that would make a difference. I worry it won’t really stop the racing thoughts. I want to get better sleep, but I don’t know if anything will actually work for me.

It sounds like you’re open to trying something, like writing down your thoughts, but you’re also unsure if it would really make a difference, given how overwhelming those racing thoughts can feel. You’re balancing a strong desire for change with some doubt about whether it’s possible, and that shows how torn you are right now. Even taking small steps might feel uncertain, but they could also help you see what does or doesn’t work for you. What would it mean for you if something like this actually started to make a difference?

It would mean a lot if it did work because I really need to find some way to feel rested and less stressed. I just don’t want to waste my time on something that might not help, you know? It’s hard to feel hopeful about it.

It’s understandable to worry about putting energy into something that might not work, especially when you’re already feeling so stressed and exhausted. Feeling unsure about whether changes can help makes it harder to feel hopeful, but it’s important to acknowledge the effort you’re willing to consider making to feel better. You’re showing a lot of thought and care for your well-being and your family, even when it feels tough. What would it take for you to feel ready to try something small and see how it goes?

I think I’d need to remind myself that making even a small effort is better than staying stuck. Maybe if I committed to trying something for just a week, like writing down my thoughts before bed, I could see if it makes any difference. I’m still hesitant, but I know I need to do *something*.

That sounds like a thoughtful and realistic approach—starting with just a week to see if writing down your thoughts makes even a small difference. It shows you’re willing to take a step forward, even with some hesitation, which is a meaningful way to start addressing the stress and sleeplessness you’ve been feeling. Is there anything else you’d want to talk through or consider before giving it a try?
I think I might be okay for now. Thank you for listening and helping me think this through. I’ll try to give the journaling a shot and see if it helps. I appreciate the support.
